rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 16–31
rsbNotes.text: 16:1–31:13 These chapters narrate David’s rise to power and Saul’s fall from power and his death. David’s rise is marked by his anointing by Samuel and his time in Saul’s service (chs. 16–18), his flight from Saul (chs. 19–23), his avoidance of bloodguilt (chs. 24–26), and his escape to the Philistines (chs. 27–31).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:1
rsbNotes.text:
22:1 cave of Adullam. Adullam, which may mean “refuge,” has been identified with a site seventeen miles southwest of Jerusalem, midway between Gath and Hebron. See also 2 Sam. 23:13; Josh. 12:15; titles to Ps. 57 and 142.

his father’s house . . . went down there to him. The vehemence that drove Saul to attack even his own family (20:33) left David’s family with little reason to feel secure.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:3
rsbNotes.text:
22:3 Mizpeh of Moab. The specific location of this city is unknown. On the name Mizpeh (“watchtower”), see 7:5 note.

king of Moab. Moab had a king already in Judg. 3:12.

stay with you. David’s decision to seek sanctuary in Moab may be based not only on the assumption that a nation at odds with Saul (14:47) might well wish to side with a rival, but also on David’s family ties to the Moabites (Ruth 4:13–17).

what God will do for me. While taking whatever practical measures he can, David nevertheless sees God in sovereign control of his situation (2 Sam. 15:25, 26).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:4
rsbNotes.text: 22:4 the stronghold. See note 23:14.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:5
rsbNotes.text: 22:5 prophet Gad. Later to serve as King David’s seer (2 Sam. 24:11; 2 Chr. 29:25; cf. 1 Chr. 29:29), Gad’s presence at this point is a reminder that David’s destiny is divinely appointed and that he is under the Lord’s protection. David will later be joined by a priest (vv. 20–23).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:6
rsbNotes.text: 22:6 spear in his hand. The mention of Saul’s spear here may be a reminder of Saul’s violent temper (18:10, 11; 19:10; 20:33), which comes to full expression in this episode.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:7
rsbNotes.text:
22:7 people of Benjamin. Having apparently surrounded himself with members of his own tribe (9:1, 2; 10:21), Saul seeks to reinforce their loyalty with an appeal to self-interest: is David, of the tribe of Judah, likely to be fair to Benjaminites?

fields and vineyards. The questions addressed by Saul to his officials suggest that he engaged in at least some of the abusive royal practices about which Samuel had warned (8:10–18).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:8
rsbNotes.text: 22:8 when my son makes a covenant. See notes 18:3, 4.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:9
rsbNotes.text:
22:9 Doeg the Edomite. See 21:7 and note.

Ahimelech the son of Ahitub. See 21:1 and notes.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:13
rsbNotes.text:
22:13 conspired against me. Saul’s assumption that Ahimelech has plotted with David against the king is baseless; Ahimelech was simply misled by David (21:2 note).

risen against me, to lie in wait. Saul’s assumption of hostile motives on David’s part is as ill-founded as his assumption about Ahimelech.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:14
rsbNotes.text: 22:14 captain over your bodyguard. Ahimelech may still think that David was doing covert work for Saul (21:2) when he came for help.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:17
rsbNotes.text: 22:17 would not . . . strike the priests. Saul’s command that the priests of the Lord be slaughtered is so evil and irrational that his own men refuse to carry it out. At least once before, Saul’s men found it necessary to go against him (14:45 and note).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:18
rsbNotes.text:
22:18 killed . . . eighty-five persons. See note 2:31.

linen ephod. See note 2:18.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:19
rsbNotes.text: 22:19 both man and woman, child and infant. It is an irony extremely damaging to Saul’s image that the description of the total slaughter of the inhabitants of Nob, “the city of the priests,” matches almost verbatim the order that had been given for the slaughter of the Amalekites (15:3) that Saul failed to carry out.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:20
rsbNotes.text: 22:20 Abiathar . . . fled after David. Support for David continues to build, chiefly as a result of Saul’s own misguided attempts at self-preservation. David now has the support of both prophet (v. 5) and priest. Abiathar brings to David the ephod (23:6), which was a means of discerning the Lord’s will (2:28 note; 14:3 note).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 22:22
rsbNotes.text: 22:22 I have occasioned. It would be easy for David to excuse himself for the massacre at Nob by simply condemning Saul. Instead, he readily admits his own share of responsibility for the disaster (21:2 note). In this admission the reader glimpses a major difference between David and his predecessor, the quality of their repentance (15:24–26, 30 and notes; 2 Sam. 12:13 note).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:1
rsbNotes.text:
23:1 Keilah. Located about three miles south of Adullam (22:1) near Philistine territory, Keilah is also mentioned in Josh. 15:44.

robbing the threshing floors. Cf. Judg. 6:3–6.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:6
rsbNotes.text: 23:6 ephod. Not the “linen ephod” traditionally worn by all priests (cf. 22:18), but the ephod associated with divine inquiry (2:28 note).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:7
rsbNotes.text: 23:7 God has given him into my hand. Saul’s interpretation of events is without foundation, as the narrator’s diametrically opposed assertion makes clear: “God did not give him into his hand” (v. 14).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:12
rsbNotes.text: 23:12 Will the men of Keilah surrender me. In view of Saul’s ruthless treatment of the city of Nob, the behavior of the Keilahites probably reflects fear rather than ingratitude to David.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:13
rsbNotes.text: 23:13 men, who were about six hundred. The growth of David’s company from four hundred (22:2) to six hundred is an indication of his increasing strength (22:20 note).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:14
rsbNotes.text:
23:14 strongholds in the wilderness. The term “strongholds” suggests a geographical area and not a single location (22:4; 2 Sam. 5:17; 23:14).

Wilderness of Ziph. The village of Ziph is thirteen miles southeast of Keilah and five miles southeast of Hebron. The wilderness would be the desert area south of Hebron. Ziph is mentioned in Josh. 15:55, along with Maon (v. 24) and Carmel (15:12; 25:2).

God did not give him into his hand. God is in sovereign control of David’s destiny (v. 7; 22:20 and notes).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:16
rsbNotes.text: 23:16 Jonathan, Saul’s son . . . strengthened his hand in God. No longer ignorant of his father’s malevolence toward David (contrast 20:2), Jonathan acts as a true friend by aiding David in finding strength where true strength can alone be found. See 30:6, where David once more “strengthened himself in the Lord his God.”

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:17
rsbNotes.text:
23:17 I shall be next to you. Though Jonathan will not survive to serve David (31:2), his readiness to let go of personal ambition for the sake of God’s chosen king (18:4; 20:13) is a foil to Saul’s desperate efforts to hang on to a kingdom that is no longer his (15:23).

Saul . . . knows this. See 20:30, 31. Saul’s refusal to accept his rejection (compare Eli’s response in 3:18) cannot be excused on the grounds that he does not know to whom the kingdom should go.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:18
rsbNotes.text: 23:18 covenant. See notes 18:3, 4.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:19
rsbNotes.text:
23:19 Ziphites. See note on v. 14; 26:1.

Gibeah. This was Saul’s hometown (10:26).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:24
rsbNotes.text: 23:24 wilderness of Maon. About eight miles south of Hebron, Maon is mentioned in 25:2 as the hometown of Nabal.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:27
rsbNotes.text: 23:27 Philistines have made a raid against the land. The providential timing of this Philistine incursion is obvious.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:28
rsbNotes.text: 23:28 Saul returned from pursuing after David. Saul distinguishes himself by sacrificing personal concerns for the sake of national security.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 23:29
rsbNotes.text: 23:29 strongholds of Engedi. Engedi was a large spring on the steep western shore of the Dead Sea. Its vicinity afforded David provisions and protection in his flight from Saul.
